description: From 16th-century criminal slang, likely from abet or Old English bætan (“to make better”); or from Old French abeter (“to entice”), from a- (“to”) + beter (“hound on, urge, to bait”); but in either case ultimately from Proto-Germanic. More at abet.

entries.meaning: A wager, an agreement between two parties that a stake (usually money) will be paid by the loser to the winner (the winner being the one who correctly forecast the outcome of an event).
examples: Dylan owes Fletcher $30 from an unsuccessful bet.

entries.meaning: (Philippines, figuratively, informal, by extension) A candidate (for elections and pageants).

examples: It’s a safe bet that it will rain tomorrow.
There's a decent bet that we'll be able to reach the top of that hill in an hour.
It’s an even bet that Jim will come top of the maths test tomorrow.
There's a good bet that Sally will arrive later.

verbs.description: bet (third-person singular simple present bets, present participle betting, simple past and past participle bet or betted)

entries.meaning: To stake or pledge upon the outcome of an event; to wager.
examples: I'll bet you two to one I'll make him do it.

entries.meaning: To be sure of something; to be able to count on something.
examples: Fancy going for a drink after work?You bet I do!

entries.meaning: (poker) To place money into the pot in order to require others do the same, usually only used for the first person to place money in the pot on each round.
